tn.ref: Solomon's fame concerning the name of Yahweh
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "Solomon's fame, which glorified Yahweh" or 2) "Solomon's fame, which Yahweh had given him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: all that was in her heart
tn.text: This is a generalization. AT: "everything she wanted to know" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Possible meanings are 1) "how his servants were seated around the table" or 2) "where his servants lived."

tn.ref: there was no more breath in her
tn.text: This is an idiom. AT: "she was utterly amazed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: I heard in my own land
tn.text: "I heard while I was in my own land"
Here the word "wisdom" can describe the word "words." AT: "your wise sayings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hendiadys]]).
The eye is a metonym for the person. AT: "I have seen it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This can be expressed positively and stated in active form. AT: "People told me very little" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is an idiom. AT: "who are always in your presence waiting to serve you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: May Yahweh your God be praised
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "May people praise Yahweh your God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: who placed you on the throne of Israel
tn.text: The throne is a metonym for the king who sits on it. AT: "who made you king of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
A talent is a unit of weight equal to about 34 kilograms. AT: "about 4,000 kilograms of gold" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]])

tn.ref: No greater amount of spices ... was ever given to him again
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "No one ever again gave to King Solomon more spices than the queen of Sheba gave to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do this. AT: "The king told his people to make" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
a type of wood, possibly one with a pleasant scent (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "nor has anyone ever seen such a great quantity again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This means to the day that the author was writing this.

tn.ref: everything she wished for, whatever she asked
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"because as king he had so much"
"each year" (UDB). This refers to every year of Solomon's reign, and not to just one time.
A talent is a unit of weight equal to about 34 kilograms. AT: "almost 23,000 kilograms of gold" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]])
It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do this. AT: "King Solomon's men made" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"200 large shields" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
A shekel is a unit of weight equal to about 11 grams. AT: "About 6.6 kilograms of gold" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]])

Because the word "shekels" does not appear here in the Hebrew text, some modern versions assume instead the unit of bekah, which was equivalent to only a half shekel. Any version making this assumption would signal a metric equivalent of about three kilograms.
It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do this. AT: "The king's men also made" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"300 shields" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
A mina is a unit of weight equal to about 600 grams. AT: "About 1.8 kilograms of gold" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]])

tn.ref: the Palace of the Forest of Lebanon
tn.text: "the house called the House of the Lebanon Forest." Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:07:01|7:2]].
It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped the king do this. AT: "the king's men made" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Ivory is the hard, white substance from the tusks or teeth of large animals. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

tn.ref: the Palace of the Forest of Lebanon
tn.text: "the house called the House of the Lebanon Forest." Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:07:01|7:2]].
Ivory is the hard, white substance from the tusks or teeth of large animals. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:10:18|10:18]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

These animals live wild in Africa. At the ends of their four limbs are what look like human hands and feet, and they have long tails. Some people consider baboons a type of ape. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
This is a generalization. AT: "People from everywhere" or "People from many different places" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

The presence of the person is a metonym for being able to speak and listen to the person. AT: "sought an audience with Solomon" or "wanted to visit Solomon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: to hear his wisdom, which God had put in his heart
tn.text: The heart is a metonym for what a person thinks and is spoken of as if it were a container. The abstract noun "wisdom" is spoken of as if it were an object that could be put in a container and can be translated as an adjective. It can be a metonym for either the person or the words the person speaks. AT: "to hear his wisdom, which God had given him" or "to hear how wise God had enabled him to be" or "to hear him speak the wise words that God had enabled him to speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"1,400 chariots and 12,000 horsemen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: The king had silver in Jerusalem, as much as the stones on the ground
tn.text: The narrator uses hyperbole to emphasize the great amount of silver that was in Jerusalem. AT: "The king had so much silver in Jerusalem, it was like there was as much silver as there was stones on the ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: that had been bought from Egypt
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "that his merchants had bought from people in Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "His merchants purchased chariots" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: six hundred shekels of silver ... 150 shekels
tn.text: A shekel is a unit of weight equal to about 11 grams. AT: "about 6.6 kilograms of silver ... about 1.7 kilograms" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]])
"600 shekels of silver" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: Many of these were then sold
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "His merchants then sold many of these" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
